newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ Tourism Board says survey average may mislead.
newsitem.headline: NZ Tourism Board says survey average may mislead.

text.p: The New Zealand Tourism Board said on Tuesday that the new Commercial Accommodation Survey national average did not fairly represent the whole industry.
The survey tracks the overnight stays of domestic and international vistors at every GST-registered accommodation provider in New Zealand and has been operated by Statistics NZ since July.
"Low occupancy in the camping ground/campervan sector over winter has skewed results for the rest of the accommodation industry," said deputy chief excutive of the Board, Chris Ryan.
He said this had resulted in a low overall national occupancy rate of around 30 percent.

Predictably the winter months have seen the camping grounds and campervan parks record the lowest overall occupancy rates of around seven to eight percent compared to 52 percent for motels and 50 percent for hotels.
Hotel and backpacker accommodation achieved an average occupancy of 39 percent in September, little changed from 40 percent and 38 percent in the two previous months.
The survey is designed to enable regional tourism organisations to compare accurately visitor accommodation stays and origin between regions.
